bug.summary: Print Alignment in hub_utils not working
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h2>üêõ Bug</denchmark-h>
I can't use the print_alignment option when using the TransformerModel translate option. <denchmark-h:h3>To Reproduce</denchmark-h>
Steps to reproduce the behavior (always include the command you ran): <denchmark-code>from fairseq.models.transformer import TransformerModel zh2en = TransformerModel.from_pretrained( '/path/to/checkpoints', checkpoint_file='checkpoint_best.pt', data_name_or_path='data-bin/wmt17_zh_en_full', bpe='subword_nmt', bpe_codes='data-bin/wmt17_zh_en_full/zh.code' ) zh2en.translate('‰Ω†Â•Ω ‰∏ñÁïå', verbose=True,print_alignment=True) </denchmark-code>
<denchmark-h:h4>Code sample</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-code>from fairseq.models.transformer import TransformerModel zh2en = TransformerModel.from_pretrained( '/path/to/checkpoints', checkpoint_file='checkpoint_best.pt', data_name_or_path='data-bin/wmt17_zh_en_full', bpe='subword_nmt', bpe_codes='data-bin/wmt17_zh_en_full/zh.code' ) zh2en.translate('‰Ω†Â•Ω ‰∏ñÁïå', verbose=True,print_alignment=True) </denchmark-code>
<denchmark-h:h3>Expected behavior</denchmark-h>
I want it to print the alignment row to console just as the fairseq-generate script does. <denchmark-h:h3>Environment</denchmark-h>
fairseq 0.9 PyTorch 1.4 OS (e.g., Linux): Linux How you installed fairseq (pip, source): pip Python version: 3.6.8 CUDA/cuDNN version: cuda 10.1

comments.comment:
huh, I've just stumbled upon the exact same problem. I would like to use alignments and searched in the codebase on how to get them. I found this:
fairseq/fairseq/hub_utils.py
Line 186 in 42f65d6
if hypo['alignment'] is not None and getarg('print_alignment', False):
It looks like alignments should be printed if both verbose and print_alignment are set to True. So I tried the following sample code: <denchmark-code>import torch
en2fr = torch.hub.load('pytorch/fairseq', 'transformer.wmt14.en-fr', tokenizer='moses', bpe='subword_nmt') fr = en2fr.translate('Hello world!', beam=5, verbose=True, print_alignment=True) </denchmark-code>
and it produces the error message: AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'int'

After some more browsing of the codebase, I made a workaround. Rewrite the last line of the sample method like this: <denchmark-code> def sample(self, sentences: List[str], beam: int = 1, verbose: bool = False, **kwargs) -> List[str]: if isinstance(sentences, str): return self.sample([sentences], beam=beam, verbose=verbose, **kwargs)[0] tokenized_sentences = [self.encode(sentence) for sentence in sentences] batched_hypos = self.generate(tokenized_sentences, beam, verbose, **kwargs) return list(zip([self.decode(hypos[0]['tokens']) for hypos in batched_hypos], [hypos[0]['alignment'] for hypos in batched_hypos])) </denchmark-code>
and it will return both the translation and the alignment. Here is the line of code to be edited as a permalink:
fairseq/fairseq/hub_utils.py
Line 133 in 42f65d6
return [self.decode(hypos[0]['tokens']) for hypos in batched_hypos]
Please note though that this will still only work if you pass in print_alignment=True as one of the kwargs.

From what i see the problematic line is:
fairseq/fairseq/hub_utils.py
Line 188 in 42f65d6
' '.join(map(lambda x: str(utils.item(x)), hypo['alignment'].int().cpu()))
it should instead be: ' '.join(['{}-{}'.format(src_idx, tgt_idx) for src_idx, tgt_idx in hypo['alignment'])
